intro: Krameria navae, commonly known as the Navajo mistletoe, is a parasitic plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Santalaceae and is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves and clusters of white, waxy flowers. The plant relies on host trees such as pines and junipers for nutrients, attaching itself to the host through haustoria. Its berries, which are red and fleshy, are an important food source for various bird species. Krameria navae plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its native habitat, contributing to the biodiversity of arid and semi-arid regions.
